column4: Miner Kinross Gold beats profit estimates on higher prices
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian miner Kinross Gold Corp beat analysts’ estimates for quarterly profit on Wednesday as a surge in gold prices cushioned the blow from lower output.
column6: Prices of the yellow metal surged 25% in 2020 as investors sought the safety of gold after the COVID-19 pandemic hammered the global economy.
column7: The company’s average realized gold price rose 26% to $1,875 per ounce, helping offset a 3.3% decline in total output to 624,032 gold equivalent ounces.
column8: Kinross Gold said it expects production to stay flat in 2021 at $2.4 million ounces of gold equivalent production.
column9: The miner also said its spending budget for this year would be unchanged from 2020 at $900 million, while annual all-in sustaining cost was forecast to rise to $1,025 per gold equivalent ounces from $970 per gold equivalent ounces in 2020.
column10: Net earnings attributable to common shareholders rose to $783.3 million, or 62 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, from $521.5 million, or 41 cents per share, a year earlier
column11: Excluding items, the miner earned 27 cents per share, beating analysts’ estimate of 22 cents, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

column4: Kinross Gold considers moving primary listing to London: The Globe and Mail
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian gold miner Kinross Gold Corp K.TO is considering moving its primary stock listing to London and selling its North and South American gold mines, The Globe and Mail reported on Friday, citing three sources familiar with the discussions.
column6: The miner is also considering doubling down on its portfolio of assets in Russia and West Africa, the report said tgam.ca/2SYrmsp.
column7: Kinross Gold believes selling its mines and redomiciling its Russian and African business to London would make the remaining parts of the company more valuable than if the assets were kept inside one business unit, the report added, citing sources.
column8: Kinross Gold officials were not immediately available to comment on the report.

column4: Chilean government sees $74 billion dollars in mining investments over a decade
column5: SANTIAGO (Reuters) - Chile expects $74 billion in mining investment in the next decade, driven mainly by the copper industry, the country´s top exporter, state copper agency Cochilco, said on Wednesday.
column6: The roster of investments includes sprawling projects from such top global miners as Antofagasta Plc ANTO.L, Lundin Mining Corp LUN.TO, Teck Resources Ltd TECKb.TO and Kinross Gold Corp K.TO. But the agency noted that 23 projects valued at $44 billion have been delayed because of coronavirus.
column7: Mining Minister Baldo Prokurica said that the copper industry represents 89.4% of the country´s total investments, and said he was nonetheless optimistic about the big investments soon to come.
column8: “Despite the coronavirus pandemic, which has strongly impacted the economy, employment and future projections, the mining sector has continued to be a (driver),” Prokurica told reporters.
column9: Cochilco said the lithium industry is also poised to expand as demand increases for the white metal, a key ingredient in the batteries that power electric vehicles.

column4: Kinross Gold CEO sees 'very low' risk of unrest spreading to Mauritania
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian gold miner Kinross Gold K.TO said it saw a "very low" risk of political unrest in Mali spreading to Mauritania, its neighbour to the north where Kinross has a gold mine with plans to expand.
column6: “We don’t see the Mali issue coming to Mauritania,” CEO Paul Rollinson told the Gold Forum Americas conference.
column7: Mali’s president was toppled in a coup last month, further destabilising a country battling a jihadist insurgency and civil unrest.
column8: Kinross’s Tasiast mine in Mauritania produced 391,097 ounces of gold equivalent in 2019. Its West African operations - Tasiast, and Chirano in Ghana - together account for 23% of the miner’s overall gold production.
column9: The company in June resolved a dispute with Mauritania’s government, securing the development of its new project Tasiast Sud.
column10: Kinross last week announced plans to boost output and reinstated a quarterly dividend for the first time since 2013.

column4: Kinross Gold CEO sees "very low" risk of unrest spreading to Mauritania
column5: Sept 21 (Reuters) - Canadian gold miner Kinross Gold said it saw a “very low” risk of political unrest in Mali spreading to Mauritania, its neighbour to the north where Kinross has a gold mine with plans to expand.
column6: “We don’t see the Mali issue coming to Mauritania,” CEO Paul Rollinson told the Gold Forum Americas conference.
column7: Mali’s president was toppled in a coup last month, further destabilising a country battling a jihadist insurgency and civil unrest. (Reporting by Helen Reid and Jeff Lewis, Editing by David Evans)

column4: Kinross Gold resolves Mauritania disputes and secures expansion
column5: JOHANNESBURG (Reuters) - Canadian mining firm Kinross Gold on Monday said it reached an agreement with Mauritania’s government under which the company will pay a total of $25 million to resolve disputes over fuel use, tax exemptions, and mining licences.
column6: Under the deal, the government will give Kinross a 30-year exploitation licence for its new project Tasiast Sud. Mauritania will receive a 15% free carried interest in the project, with an option to purchase an additional 10% after further feasibility work is completed.
column7: The deal terms are similar to those agreed by Barrick Gold in January when it ended a long-running tax dispute with Tanzania by giving the government a stake in three gold mines.
column8: Mauritania will reinstate a tax exemption on fuel duties and repay around $40 million in VAT refunds to Kinross, the company said in a statement.
column9: Kinross will pay the government $10 million to resolve disputes around fuel use and tax exemptions, and $15 million upon receiving the Tasiast Sud exploitation licence, to resolve disputes around its application to convert the exploration licence into an exploitation licence.
column10: It also said it would now pay an escalating royalty - tied to the price of gold - from 4% for prices below $1,000 an ounce, to 6.5% for prices of $1,800/oz and above.
column11: The gold price has soared as the global pandemic drives investors into safe-haven assets, and was last trading just above $1,700 per ounce.
column12: Kinross, whose Tasiast gold mine produced 391,097 ounces of gold last year, said the agreement further develops a “positive foreign investment climate” in Mauritania.
column13: Mines minister Mohamed Abdel Vetah said: “Tasiast is an important contributor to Mauritania and we believe our new agreement will be a positive model for other foreign mining investors”.
column14: A workers’ strike at Tasiast mine last month resulted in a two-week shutdown which the company said would not affect 2020 production.

column4: Two workers that sparked Kinross Russia gold mine lockdown test negative
column5: MOSCOW, March 20 (Reuters) - Two workers that sparked the lockdown of a gold mine in Russia’s Far East involving almost 900 workers have tested negative for the new coronavirus, local authorities said.
column6: Mine operator Kinross Gold Corp of Canada, which produces gold and silver in Russia, isolated its Kupol mine complex this week, including 866 on-site workers.
column7: The two employees had been hospitalised with suspected coronavirus infections in the biggest mining lockdown since the outbreak of the disease.
column8: The company did not respond to a request for immediate comment regarding when it might lift its lockdown.
column9: There were 199 confirmed cases of coronavirus in Russia as of March 19, official data showed.

column4: Canada's Kinross gold mine in Russia on lockdown after coronavirus suspected
column5: MOSCOW, March 18 (Reuters) - Canada’s Kinross Gold Corp has isolated its Kupol mine in Russia’s Far East after two workers were hospitalised with suspected coronavirus infections in the biggest mining lockdown since the outbreak of the disease in December last year.
column6: The plant, which has the capacity to produce 4,500 tonnes of ore a day, is continuing to operate on schedule, but its output is not being shipped, a spokesman said.
column7: Air links to the remote mine, located in the Chukotka region, 400 km (248.55 miles) northwest of the city of Anadyr, have been suspended and its winter road route, a snow and ice overland connection, has been closed off.
column8: Both workers are currently hospitalised in Anadyr, awaiting the results of their coronavirus tests. The region has no confirmed cases of the new disease, which has infected 204,000 globally, including 147 confirmed cases in Russia.
column9: Contacts between the mine complex, where 866 employees are currently located, and another of the company’s plants located 100 km away have been put on hold.
column10: “The plant is continuing its operations, and serious prophylactic measures have been taken. Work is ongoing under self-isolation conditions,” the spokesman said, adding that Kupol’s employees are under medical surveillance.
column11: One of the hospitalised workers had returned to Russia from Verona in Italy, an epicentre of the outbreak, in late February, Russia’s consumer health and safety watchdog said. (Reporting by Anastasia Lyrchikova; Writing by Polina Ivanova; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)

column4: BRIEF-Kinross Gold Says Employee From Toronto Office Tested Positive For Covid-19 Virus
column6: * KINROSS GOLD CORP - WAS INFORMED ON MARCH 10, 2020 THAT AN EMPLOYEE FROM ITS TORONTO OFFICE TESTED POSITIVE FOR COVID-19 VIRUS
column7: * KINROSS GOLD CORP - HAS ASKED EMPLOYEES TO WORK FROM HOME UNTIL AT LEAST MARCH 20 WHEN NEED FOR CLOSURE WILL BE RE-EVALUATED
column8: * KINROSS GOLD CORP - TO DATE, COVID-19 HAS NOT IMPACTED PRODUCTION OR PRODUCT SHIPMENTS AT ANY OF COMPANY’S SITES
column9: * KINROSS GOLD CORP - ACTIVATED ITS BUSINESS CONTINUITY PROGRAM TO HELP ENSURE THAT HEAD OFFICE FUNCTIONS ARE MAINTAINED WHILE EMPLOYEES WORK REMOTELY
column10: * KINROSS GOLD - COVID-19 POSITIVE EMPLOYEE DID NOT ATTEND PDAC CONFERENCE OR OTHER EXTERNAL EVENTS AND HAS NOT RECENTLY TRAVELLED TO KINROSS SITES
column11: * KINROSS GOLD CORP - TO DATE, NOT BEEN ANY SIGNIFICANT NEGATIVE IMPACT ON, OR DISRUPTION OF, COMPANY’S SUPPLY CHAIN DUE TO COVID-19 Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: Kinross Gold profit beats on higher gold prices, output
column5: (Reuters) - Canadian miner Kinross Gold Corp K.TO reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit on Wednesday, helped by record output at its third biggest mine, Tasiast, and higher gold prices.
column6: Gold prices rose 18% in 2019, as investors sought safety in safe-havens due to political uncertainty, U.S.-China trade war and concerns on slowing global growth.
column7: The company’s average realized gold price rose 21% to $1,485 per ounce from $1,226 an year earlier, while total production rose 5.8% to 645,344 gold equivalent ounces (Au eq. oz.).
column8: The miner forecast production of about 2.4 million Au eq. oz. for 2020, a decrease compared with its 2019 production of 2.5 million Au eq. oz., due to care and maintenance at its Maricunga mine in Chile and expected lower output at its largest mine Paracatu, which posted record production in 2019.
column9: Kinross posted net earnings of $521.5 million, or 41 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, due to higher margins and non-cash impairment reversals of $361.8 million. The company posted a loss of $27.7 million, or 2 cents per share, a year earlier.
column10: Excluding items, the company earned 13 cents per share, beating analysts’ average estimate of 10 cents, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column12: U.S.-listed shares of the miner were up 2.4% at $5.12 after the bell.

column4: Kinross Gold adjusted profit jumps on higher gold prices, output
column5: Feb 12 (Reuters) - Canadian miner Kinross Gold Corp reported a jump in quarterly adjusted profit on Wednesday, helped by record output at its third biggest mine Tasiast, and higher gold prices that boosted margins.
column6: The company’s adjusted profit rose to $156 million, or 13 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, from $13.5 million, or 1 cent per share, a year earlier.
column7: The company’s total production rose to 645,344 gold equivalent ounces from 610,152 gold equivalent ounces a year earlier.
column8: Average realized gold prices rose 21% to $1,485 per ounce from $1,226 an year earlier. (Reporting by Nishara Karuvalli Pathikkal in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: Canada's Kinross hits pause on Russia after gold project deal
column5: CALGARY/MOSCOW, Sept 30 (Reuters) - Canada’s Kinross Gold Corp is putting future deals in Russia on hold after snapping up a development project in a country hit by Western sanctions.
column6: The Toronto-based miner in July acquired the undeveloped Chulbatkan asset from closely held N-Mining for $283 million in cash and shares.
column7: The acquisition will add 3.9 million indicated ounces of gold to Kinross’ books, according to the company.
column8: Foreign investment in new mining projects in Russia has grown scarce due to Western sanctions levelled after the 2014 annexation by Russia of Crimea from Ukraine.
column9: The deal with N-Mining does not breach any sanctions but still requires Russian approval.
column10: The deal follows a years-long effort by Kinross Chief Executive Paul Rollinson to cultivate ties in Russia even as diplomatic relations with the West – including Canada – have soured.
column11: “If you own our stock, by definition you’re comfortable with Russia, but that doesn’t mean we want to go overboard,” Rollinson told Reuters.
column12: Kinross was offered several larger assets in Russia over the last couple of years but was not willing to spend too much on the country, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters.
column13: Kinross considered buying a gold project from Highland Gold Mining Ltd, another gold producer in Russia, but the companies did not agree on the price, an industry source told Reuters. Highland Gold declined to comment.
column14: Russian operations accounted for one-fifth of 2018 revenue for Kinross, according to Refinitiv data.
column15: Kinross has poured more than $3.5 billion into Russia since 1995, making it the biggest foreign investor in the country’s gold sector and the third-largest producer of gold equivalent behind Polyus and Polymetal International Plc , according to Russia’s gold producers’ union, a non-government lobby group.
column16: Russia’s anti-monopoly regulator told Reuters last week that it had recently extended the review of the Chulbatkan acquisition by two months.
column17: A Kinross spokesman said it expects the deal to close as scheduled early next year.
column18: The Russia asset has a six-year mine life with an initial development cost of $500 million, Kinross said. But production will not start for at least five years, and some analysts said the company will need to show sizeable finds during exploration to make it add value.
column19: Buoyed by gold’s rally above $1,500 per ounce, investors have pushed Kinross shares up by a third since the deal was announced, versus a 7% rise in the VanEck Vectors Gold Miners exchange-traded fund.

column4: Gold at $1,500 is a new price floor, Kinross CEO says
column5: DENVER (Reuters) - Gold prices look to have established a new floor at $1,500 per ounce, Kinross Gold Corp’s chief executive officer said on Monday, giving the Canadian miner confidence to push ahead with expansion plans at a key West African mine.
column6: “I don’t see a lot of technical barriers above it, but I do believe that there’s people buying in to where we are today,” Paul Rollinson told Reuters at the Denver Gold Forum.
column7: Kinross on Sunday said it would spend $150-million to boost capacity its Tasiast gold mine in Mauritania to 24,000 tonnes per day by 2023.
column8: Kinross’s Toronto-listed shares were up 3.5% on Monday.
column9: Last year, the company shelved a larger, $600-million expansion at the mine after the government requested talks to improve the country’s economic benefits from the miner’s activities.
column10: Kinross had initially aimed to grow daily processing capacity at the mine to 30,000 tonnes per day after earlier boosting mill throughput to 12,000 tonnes per day from 8,000 tonnes.
column11: It said the smaller expansion would use existing equipment and require minor upgrades in the plant and forecast an internal rate of return of 60% based on a gold price of $1,200 per ounce.
column12: “We’re getting to the finish line with way less capital,” Rollinson said. He said the company expects $300 million in project financing to be in place later this fall.
column13: The company remains in talks with the newly elected government over taxes and procurement, issues Rollinson said were “manageable.” He did not provide a timeline for a resolution.
column14: “Mauritania is a country that is still seeking foreign investment and we are a lens for the world, and they know that,” he said.
column15: The company also on Sunday said it had signed a three-year labor agreement in principle with the mine’s unionized workers, replacing a previous deal that had been set to expire in November.
column16: “This go-ahead decision reduces uncertainty surrounding potential expansion plans and the ongoing discussions on shared benefits from Tasiast with the Mauritanian government,” RBC Dominion Securities Inc. analyst Stephen Walker said in a research note.

column4: Gold at $1,500 a new price floor, Kinross CEO says
column5: DENVER, Sept 16 (Reuters) - Gold prices look to have established a new floor at $1,500 per ounce, Kinross Gold Corp’s chief executive officer said on Monday, giving the Canadian miner confidence to push ahead with expansion plans at a key West African mine.
column6: “I don’t see a lot of technical barriers above it, but I do believe that there’s people buying in to where we are today,” Paul Rollinson told Reuters at the Denver Gold Forum.
column7: Kinross on Sunday said it would spend $150-million to boost capacity its Tasiast gold mine in Mauritania to 24,000 tonnes per day by 2023. (Reporting by Jeff Lewis)

column4: UPDATE 1-Chile's Supreme Court signals death knell for Kinross gold mine
column6: Oct 10 (Reuters) - Chile’s Supreme Court upheld an environmental order for a gold mine owned by Canada’s Kinross Gold Corp to close its water pumping wells, the environmental regulator said on Wednesday, bringing the curtain down on a long-running dispute that sparked the Toronto-based miner’s retreat from Chile.
column7: The environmental watchdog, known locally as the SMA, initially ordered that the wells serving the Maricunga mine be shut down in 2016. The ruling was challenged by Kinross in Chile’s environmental tribunal and then in the country’s highest court.
column8: The Supreme Court on Wednesday backed the original order, pointing to the “inadequate management of unforeseen environmental impacts on the Pantanillo-Ciénaga Redonda basin,” which is located in northern Chile’s Atacama Desert.
column9: Kinross told Reuters it was analyzing the decision’s implications on potential future operations at the mine.
column10: “Mining at Maricunga was suspended in Q4 2016 and the decision is not expected to impact the status quo,” a spokeswoman said.
column11: Kinross, the world’s fourth largest gold miner by output in 2017, halted all extraction, grinding and stockpiling of ore in the fourth quarter of 2016 and laid off 300 staff after the original ruling in March of that year.
column12: At the time, local news media quoted the company as saying that environmental damage in the area had been caused by drought rather than extraction operations.
column13: The Maricunga mine accounted for 8 percent of the company’s total gold production in 2015. (Reporting by Fabian Cambero and Aislinn Laing; writing by Dave Sherwood, editing by Jonathan Oatis and G Crosse)

column4: Chile's Supreme Court signals death knell of Kinross gold mine

column6: The environmental watchdog, known locally as the SMA, initially ordered that the wells serving the Maricunga mine be shut down in 2016. The ruling was challenged by Kinross in Chile’s environmental tribunal and then in the country’s highest court.
column7: The Supreme Court on Wednesday backed the original order, pointing to the “inadequate management of unforeseen environmental impacts on the Pantanillo-Ciénaga Redonda basin”, which is located in Chile’s northern Atacama desert.
column8: Kinross, the world’s fourth largest gold miner by output in 2017, halted all extraction, grinding and stockpiling of ore and laid off 300 staff in the fourth quarter of 2016 after the original ruling in March that year.
column9: At the time, local news media quoted the company as saying that environmental damage in the area had been caused by drought rather than extraction operations.
column10: The Maricunga mine accounted for 8 percent of the company’s total gold production in 2015. (Reporting by Fabian Cambero and Aislinn Laing; editing by Jonathan Oatis)
